text: DOCTOR: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.

PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay. The CAT scan also looks good. Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. That’s good. That’s pleasing isn’t it J___.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
PATIENT: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: We’re frustrated.
DOCTOR: But he’s doing okay?
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: He’s having some back pain.
DOCTOR: Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: We’re just kind of…
DOCTOR: Show me where. (paper shuffling)
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah that’s what we wanted, that’s what we did. We just did it though.

PATIENT: Not – a little bit.
DOCTOR: A little bit. Not too bad though.
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: Is there anything that brings on the pain?
DOCTOR: A fracture now would really set us back. So-
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes because we have brittle bones.

DOCTOR: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often.
FAMILY MEMBER: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ -
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: -and keep him from harm.
DOCTOR: Yep.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because we’re doing
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: a little bit better
DOCTOR: Was he not taking Metformin at all?
FAMILY MEMBER: No he’s got – they told him – and they reminded him today because of the alteration in his kidney function,
DOCTOR: Oh okay because of that.
FAMILY MEMBER: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor
DOCTOR: Mm Hmm.
FAMILY MEMBER: before all this treatment even started.
DOCTOR: Really?
FAMILY MEMBER: She was like…
DOCTOR: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah
DOCTOR: Between your kidney’s failing and hurting and the infections, I mean there were multiple other things that were being thrown at us.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah and he’s showing an improvement in between – in most all areas…
DOCTOR: The treatment is working and things are looking up.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: That’s why we’re so glad to be here but you’ve got some people that were mean to us this morning.
DOCTOR: Really?
PATIENT: Um hum.
PATIENT: Well I wasn’t out there. So I’m glad I wasn’t out there. DOC
DOCTOR: Well that was not appropriate.

FAMILY MEMBER: And the point is in situations like that you can’t join a group, you can’t join a crowd, you have to stand out in a separate entity and say well I’m not gonna stoop to their level but I’m not gonna be stupid either.
DOCTOR: Yeah so if are issues along the way –
FAMILY MEMBER: They gave me this application to fill out.
DOCTOR: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or…
DOCTOR: Yeah, I know.
FAMILY MEMBER: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given -
DOCTOR: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because you care, that she listens.
DOCTOR: But and I have also have some donor money
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If you know, for medical expenses
FAMILY MEMBER: Mm Hmm.
DOCTOR: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: Alright
FAMILY MEMBER: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.
DOCTOR: Of course.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Maybe S__ was waiting?
DOCTOR: Yeah. Walgreens, Walmart,
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Walmart pharmacy (phone dialing)
DOCTOR: Oh you’re gonna call them and ask, perfect.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay. I will be back. I have to have S__ check and see but next time I’m gonna check your sugar so come and in fasting to get you blood work.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Then you can eat. Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: It’s almost like a motivation machine.
DOCTOR: Wow.
FAMILY MEMBER: It doesn’t make him drowsy at all.
DOCTOR: Now, does it uh cause you any problems, though? The Norco doesn’t constipate you?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: Does it help with the pain?
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up.
FAMILY MEMBER: It went up. Yes.
DOCTOR: From four to nine.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?
DOCTOR: No.
FAMILY MEMBER: Uh, I just picked up a full-time schedule.
DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Will he need to have somebody come with him?
DOCTOR: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made?
FAMILY MEMBER: He drives.
DOCTOR: Oh, okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere.
DOCTOR: (Laughs) . Okay. So then usually what I tell people-
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do –
FAMILY MEMBER: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new-
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah. Right.
DOCTOR: I would-
FAMILY MEMBER: You want somebody here.
DOCTOR: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit-
FAMILY MEMBER: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse.
DOCTOR: I know.
FAMILY MEMBER: I’m going to keep my eye on-
DOCTOR: (FAM & talking at the same time) That’s what I was just going to tell you that I’m going to have to lean on you a little bit more.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes. Yes.
DOCTOR: Because you have the training already.
FAMILY MEMBER: You’re going to have to listen to me, J___, okay?
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: But she said is so vitally important -
DOCTOR: - If she needs to call me –
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: - I would rather you over call than you know totally ignore - –
FAMILY MEMBER: Ignore it.
DOCTOR: - and then you get really sick by the time you show up in here.
PATIENT: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. Great.
DOCTOR: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it.
DOCTOR: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.
FAMILY MEMBER: Try something else.
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Makes sense?
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: We stand, we stand in agreement with you.
DOCTOR: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right. That’s good.
DOCTOR: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else.
FAMILY MEMBER: That’s a blessing.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So I’m good with that.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay?
DOCTOR: Okay. So should I give you a script today is what I’m thinking?
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Because uh that way you don’t have to scramble last minute.
FAMILY MEMBER: (DOC & are talking at the same time) Have to come back, yeah. Right.
DOCTOR: What is he on? The Norco, right?
FAMILY MEMBER: The Norco. He has
DOCTOR: Okay. Ten’s or?

FAMILY MEMBER: No. He’s on five. What you need to tell her now while she’s writing, do, do they take your pain completely away? The thing that bothers me is at night, he still doesn’t sleep, and you’re still in pain.
DOCTOR: So should I give you the higher dose, or do you thing?
FAMILY MEMBER: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us.
DOCTOR: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in –
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: -and give you a copy of the consent.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: But once we found out, she will be in touch.
FAMILY MEMBER: Thank you.
DOCTOR: To let you know what we’re going to do.

DOCTOR: Okay. So we’d like to check your blood test and then call you and if the PSA is not down to zero then we would consider having you get some radiation treatments and send you for a consultation with the radiation doctors.
PATIENT: Mmm.
DOCTOR: If the PSA does go down to zero then we can tell you about some additional testing that we can do.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: And we may do um your paperwork here - an appointment for six months, just kind of like a safety appointment.
PATIENT: Uh huh.
DOCTOR: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: So what you think my tests might be?
PATIENT: Yeah, at least two weeks.
DOCTOR: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Things like that.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: He does try them.
PATIENT: Yeah. That does help.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: So, okay.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take?
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Like 10?
DOCTOR: Well, you know, the reformulation is so different over the counter.
DOCTOR: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too?
DOCTOR: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted?
DOCTOR: That's hard.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Oh okay.
DOCTOR: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot.
DOCTOR: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: Can I ask you a question?
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no?
DOCTOR: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine
FAMILY MEMBER 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription?
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left.
DOCTOR: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: Restiril.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
DOCTOR: I just wont go there.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: How old is she?
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Yeah but the Mother is.
DOCTOR: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER 3: So um, we are worried about him being around the mother that is newly pregnant, she gets her first ultrasound right now. So what do you think?
DOCTOR: Well, they're, you know-
FAMILY MEMBER 1: If they ask us for dinner.
DOCTOR: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often.
DOCTOR: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth?
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning?

PATIENT: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today.
DOCTOR: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The
PATIENT: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is.
DOCTOR: And what makes you think that it’s working?
PATIENT: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses-
DOCTOR: Um hum.

PATIENT: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me.

DOCTOR: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase.
PATIENT: Um hum.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back.
FAMILY MEMBER: She’ll be here tomorrow.
DOCTOR: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that.
PATIENT: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page.
DOCTOR: Comfortable with that?
PATIENT: I am.
DOCTOR: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that?
PATIENT: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles)
FAMILY MEMBER: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question –
DOCTOR: Um hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand.

DOCTOR: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh.
FAMILY MEMBER: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know?
DOCTOR: Yeah.

FAMILY MEMBER: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing.
DOCTOR: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So.
PATIENT: Um hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day?
DOCTOR: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient.
PATIENT: Um hum.

FAMILY MEMBER: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens?
FAMILY MEMBER: I know. I tolerate this guy all by myself.
DOCTOR: I know. All by yourself.
PATIENT: Come on in and have a seat there. I’ve got friends waiting.
DOCTOR: How come I’m over here?
PATIENT: You can’t get these things together. Do you need me to get together or what? (Laughter)
DOCTOR: (Laughter) . What does he mean?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Is that on purpose for filming?
FAMILY MEMBER: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter)
DOCTOR: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: It looked like they should be in a catalog.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or.
FAMILY MEMBER: I know. Yes.
DOCTOR: Okay.
PATIENT: Just working zone. (Laughter)
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter)
DOCTOR: How you feeling?
PATIENT: I’ve been great.
DOCTOR: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: Now, in March, you were at two and a half.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: You had a shot in June. So your next one isn’t, you know, until September.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right. Right.
DOCTOR: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure.
PATIENT: Hum. Hum.
DOCTOR: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
DOCTOR: This is not a huge jump.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up.
PATIENT: Hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
DOCTOR: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so.
PATIENT: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot?
DOCTOR: No.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are.
PATIENT: (Laughter) . Hum.
DOCTOR: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things.
PATIENT: Hum.
DOCTOR: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care.
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter)
PATIENT: I get it.
DOCTOR: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it.
PATIENT: I’m with you.
DOCTOR: Because you know it was nasty when we started.
FAMILY MEMBER: I know.
DOCTOR: And we had to-.
PATIENT: Well, how can I get rid of it completely, though?
DOCTOR: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: We will continue to be as aggressive. If there is something new, we’re probably going to take a sample of that.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And see what that looks like. Check it again for profiling, blueprinting of your genetics, I mean the whole nine yards.
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: We talked about that earlier.
PATIENT: Right. Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And if it’s time we do it. You know?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: But I need to be assured as you guys do also.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: That there’s nothing new or that these guys all of a sudden didn’t wake up and go, yeah, well, we were sleeping.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: All those lymph nodes and now we’re awake. And we would know if we’re awake because it would be bigger or if it was new. Like, wait a minute.
PATIENT: Hum.
DOCTOR: That wasn’t big before, what we’ve got there.
DOCTOR: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch?
PATIENT: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch.
DOCTOR: That’s nice. Where you guys going?
PATIENT: Downtown somewhere.
DOCTOR: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there?
FAMILY MEMBER: No.
DOCTOR: It’s really good.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh. Sounds interesting.
DOCTOR: It’s, it’s, you know, on one of those Zagat books and stuff.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: It’s just, they do creative things. It’s not your standard mac and cheese.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
DOCTOR: You like it?
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good.
FAMILY MEMBER: I’ve heard of it. Okay.
DOCTOR: Right across the street.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah. Yeah.
DOCTOR: Actually, you both, you both have come a long way.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: From our first days of meeting.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right?
DOCTOR: You just being bent over and not looking at anything but the floor.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: This is great.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And you’re making music again?
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
PATIENT: I am, totally.
DOCTOR: I mean, that, you know?
PATIENT: I’m having fun.
DOCTOR: That’s a scale. I mean that’s amazing. Wow. When you’re talented, you’re talented.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And there’s nothing like cancer that’s going to stop you.
FAMILY MEMBER: No.
